Author: whacked_new
Content:
I'm curious, does a 2-3x increase in speed very perceptibly better the user experience? I can understand a 15 second to 5 second reduction. What about a 2 second to 0.6 second reduction?\nWhat about balancing by faster hardware?

(asking because it's directly relevant to me)

Author: ryantmulligan
Content: Google Checkout has rates of 2% + $.2 per transaction with no extra/hidden fees.

Author: Sam_Odio
Content:
It's great that we're all networking - but I'm not sure the news.yc discussion threads are the place to do it.

I was thinking about setting up a wiki to help co-founders post their bios & connect with others in their area...

Anyone think this would be a good idea?

Author: far33d
Content:
Blank url posts are sometimes hard to follow because the order of the comments is not chronological -- hence, It's hard to find the first comment, the actual question.

It might be nice to have a chronological sort, or maybe, for just blank url posts, to have the first comment always appear first.

Author: mukund
Content: hmm bulls eye and thats what we were trying to solve :)

Author: far33d
Content:
The biggest suffer because they are too popular: it's like trying to read through my Yahoo Mail - too much spam, recruiters making huge lists of keywords, etc. It must be just as bad on the receiving end: imagine how many terrible responses you must get to a C++ developer post on Monster.

The blog based ones are more focused, but almost to a fault. There must be a better way for people who don't want to start companies to find companies with similar interests. LinkedIn sort of helps, but there's so many recruiters on there that it feels just like Monster.

Just looking to see if anyone has any thoughts or insights. I've found all my jobs through friends...

Author: far33d
Title: Job Boards suck... What would make them better?
